The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This contains as many of (s)(...) surrounding the application of args to macro as there are elements in seq. For example, if (s) is 2, the expression
((1)(2)(3), MACRO, (...))
results in the
(2)((2)((2)( MACRO(...) )))
This , when invoked by , expands to the result of MACRO(...) scanned three additional times. I.e. the expression MACRO(...) is scanned one time more than there are elements in seq.

The primary utility of this macro is to provide for an algorithm whose recursion requirements are linear (or better) and easily computed as a from its input--while guaranting constant usage of the . This is often the case with algorithms that operate on .

A fixed number of additional steps can be added simply by adding elements, such as seq(~)(~), as the contents of each element are irrelevent.
